short_description: Spiced beef wrapped in pita with tahini and pickles.
steps: Marinate beef.
Grill or roast.
Slice thin.
Wrap with toppings.
cooking_tips: Thin slices.
Stack and slice.
nutrition_benefits: High protein, iron from beef, calcium from tahini.

short_description: Crispy chickpea fritters with herbs and spices.
steps: Soak chickpeas overnight.
Blend with herbs.
Shape.
Deep fry.
cooking_tips: Never use canned chickpeas.
Hot oil.
nutrition_benefits: Plant protein, fiber, herbs provide vitamins.

short_description: Smoky roasted eggplant dip with tahini and garlic.
steps: Char eggplant.
Scoop flesh.
Blend with tahini.
Season.
cooking_tips: Direct flame best.
Drain liquid.
nutrition_benefits: Low calorie, healthy fats from tahini.

short_description: Lebanese flatbread topped with zaatar and olive oil.
steps: Make dough.
Rise.
Stretch.
Top with zaatar oil.
Bake.
cooking_tips: Hot oven.
Fresh zaatar.
nutrition_benefits: Energy from carbs, antioxidants from zaatar.

short_description: Lebanese steak tartare with bulgur, onion, and spices.
steps: Soak bulgur.
Process lamb.
Combine.
Serve raw.
cooking_tips: Freshest lamb.
Chill all equipment.
nutrition_benefits: High protein, iron, zinc from raw lamb.

short_description: Fresh herb salad dominated by parsley with bulgur and lemon.
steps: Soak bulgur.
Chop parsley fine.
Combine.
Dress with lemon oil.
cooking_tips: More parsley than bulgur.
Very fine chop.
nutrition_benefits: Iron from parsley, vitamin K, antioxidants.

short_description: The ultimate creamy chickpea dip with tahini, lemon, and garlic. Lebanese hummus is known for its silky smooth texture and perfect balance of flavors.
steps: Blend tahini and lemon juice until smooth and light.
Add garlic and blend again.
Add chickpeas gradually while blending.
Stream in ice water while processing for extra smoothness.
Season with salt and cumin.
Blend until completely smooth, about 5 minutes.
Serve with olive oil drizzle and paprika.
Accompany with warm pita bread.
cooking_tips: Remove chickpea skins for ultra-smooth texture.
Ice water makes the hummus lighter and fluffier.
Let tahini and lemon emulsify before adding chickpeas.
nutrition_benefits: High in plant protein and fiber. Tahini provides calcium and healthy fats. Garlic offers immune-boosting properties.

short_description: A vibrant Lebanese bread salad with crispy pita chips, fresh vegetables, and tangy sumac dressing. This colorful dish celebrates the garden's bounty.
steps: Toast or fry pita bread until golden and crispy.
Break pita into bite-sized chips.
Chop all vegetables into similar-sized pieces.
Tear lettuce into large pieces.
Whisk olive oil, lemon juice, sumac, and pomegranate molasses.
Combine vegetables in a large bowl.
Toss with dressing just before serving.
Top with crispy pita chips and extra sumac.
cooking_tips: Add pita chips at the last moment to keep them crispy.
Sumac is essential for authentic flavor.
Pomegranate molasses adds a unique sweet-tart note.
nutrition_benefits: Rich in vitamins from fresh vegetables. Sumac is high in antioxidants. A light, nutritious meal perfect for hot days.

short_description: Baked kibbeh layers featuring a spiced meat and pine nut filling sandwiched between bulgur-lamb crusts. This is Lebanese comfort food at its finest.
steps: Soak bulgur in cold water for 30 minutes, drain well.
Process lean lamb with one onion and spices until paste-like.
Mix lamb paste with bulgur, kneading until smooth.
For filling, sauté diced onion in butter until soft.
Add ground lamb, cook until browned with spices.
Toast pine nuts and add to filling.
Press half the kibbeh mixture into an oiled baking pan.
Spread filling evenly, then top with remaining kibbeh.
Score into diamond shapes, drizzle with olive oil.
Bake at 180°C (350°F) for 35-40 minutes until golden.
cooking_tips: Keep hands wet when pressing kibbeh to prevent sticking.
The crust should be thin and even.
Let rest 10 minutes before cutting for clean slices.
nutrition_benefits: High in protein from lamb. Bulgur provides fiber and B vitamins. Pine nuts add healthy fats and minerals.

short_description: Tender grape leaves stuffed with fragrant rice, herbs, and sometimes meat. These delicate rolls are a labor of love and a centerpiece of Lebanese cuisine.
steps: If using jarred leaves, rinse and blanch briefly.
Mix rice with diced tomatoes, onion, and herbs.
Season with spices, half the lemon juice, and olive oil.
Place a leaf shiny-side down, remove stem.
Add a spoonful of filling near the stem.
Fold sides in, roll tightly toward the tip.
Line pot with extra leaves or potato slices.
Arrange rolls seam-side down in tight layers.
Add remaining lemon juice and water to cover.
Place a plate on top, simmer covered for 90 minutes.
cooking_tips: Don't overfill - rice expands during cooking.
Pack rolls tightly to prevent unraveling.
Serve cold or at room temperature for best flavor.
nutrition_benefits: Grape leaves are rich in vitamins A and K. The herbs provide antioxidants. A light, healthy appetizer.

short_description: Humble yet delicious, this dish of lentils and rice topped with crispy caramelized onions is a staple of Lebanese home cooking. Simple ingredients, extraordinary flavor.
steps: Cook lentils in water until almost tender, about 20 minutes.
Slice onions thinly and evenly.
Fry onions in olive oil until deeply caramelized, 25-30 minutes.
Remove most onions for topping, leaving some in the oil.
Add rice to the pot with lentils.
Add cumin and enough water to cook rice.
Cover and simmer until rice and lentils are tender.
Fluff with fork, top with crispy onions.
Serve with yogurt or fresh salad.
cooking_tips: Patience with onions - they need to be truly caramelized.
Don't stir the onions too often while frying.
The crispy onions make the dish - don't skip them!
nutrition_benefits: Excellent source of plant protein and fiber from lentils. Iron-rich and filling. A complete protein when served with yogurt.

short_description: Juicy marinated chicken sliced thin and wrapped in warm pita with garlic sauce, pickles, and fresh vegetables. Street food perfection.
steps: Mix yogurt, lemon juice, minced garlic, and spices.
Marinate chicken for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Grill or pan-fry chicken until cooked through.
Let rest, then slice thinly against the grain.
Warm pita bread.
Spread garlic sauce on pita.
Add chicken, pickles, and fresh vegetables.
Roll tightly and serve immediately.
cooking_tips: Chicken thighs stay juicier than breast.
The longer the marinade, the better the flavor.
Toum (garlic sauce) is essential for authentic taste.
nutrition_benefits: Lean protein from chicken. Yogurt marinade adds probiotics and tenderizes meat. Spices have anti-inflammatory properties.

short_description: An intensely garlicky Lebanese sauce that's fluffy, creamy, and addictively delicious. This emulsified garlic spread is the perfect accompaniment to grilled meats.
steps: Peel garlic and remove any green germs.
Blend garlic with salt until very fine.
With blender running, slowly drizzle in oil.
Alternate between oil and lemon juice.
Add ice water to stabilize if needed.
Continue until thick and fluffy.
Refrigerate for at least 30 minutes before serving.
Store in airtight container in fridge.
cooking_tips: Add oil very slowly to prevent breaking.
If sauce breaks, start with egg white and slowly add broken sauce.
Use fresh, firm garlic for best results.
nutrition_benefits: Garlic has powerful antimicrobial and immune-boosting properties. Rich in allicin and antioxidants.

short_description: Aromatic ground meat skewers seasoned with parsley, onion, and Lebanese spices. These charcoal-grilled kebabs are a beloved staple of Lebanese barbecue.
steps: Finely chop parsley and onion (or process briefly).
Mix ground meat with parsley, onion, and all spices.
Knead well until mixture is smooth and well combined.
Refrigerate for 30 minutes for easier shaping.
Shape around flat skewers in long ovals.
Grill over hot coals, turning frequently.
Cook until charred outside but juicy inside.
Serve with pita, hummus, and fresh vegetables.
cooking_tips: The more you knead, the better the texture.
Keep hands wet when shaping to prevent sticking.
Flat skewers work best for kafta.
nutrition_benefits: High in protein and iron. Parsley adds vitamin K and antioxidants. A satisfying, low-carb option.

short_description: Tender chunks of marinated chicken grilled to perfection. This Lebanese classic features a tangy yogurt and garlic marinade that keeps the chicken incredibly juicy.
steps: Cut chicken into 2-inch cubes.
Mix yogurt, lemon juice, crushed garlic, tomato paste, and spices.
Add chicken to marinade, coating well.
Refrigerate for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Thread chicken onto skewers.
Grill over medium-high heat, turning occasionally.
Cook until charred and cooked through, about 12-15 minutes.
Serve with garlic sauce and pickles.
cooking_tips: Tomato paste adds color and slight sweetness.
Don't skip the marinating time - it's essential.
Let meat come to room temperature before grilling.
nutrition_benefits: Lean protein from chicken breast. Yogurt provides calcium and probiotics. A healthy grilled option.

short_description: A layered dish of crispy pita, chickpeas, and tangy yogurt topped with toasted pine nuts. This breakfast favorite is also served for celebrations.
steps: Toast or fry pita until crispy, break into pieces.
Warm chickpeas in their liquid.
Mix yogurt with tahini, crushed garlic, lemon juice, and salt.
Toast pine nuts in butter until golden.
Layer crispy pita in a serving dish.
Moisten with some chickpea liquid.
Add chickpeas, then pour yogurt sauce over.
Top with buttered pine nuts and a sprinkle of paprika.
cooking_tips: Serve immediately so pita stays slightly crispy.
Can add cooked lamb or chicken for a heartier version.
The layers should be visible from the side.
nutrition_benefits: Protein and fiber from chickpeas. Probiotics from yogurt. Healthy fats from tahini and pine nuts.

short_description: Crispy half-moon pastries filled with spiced meat or cheese. These golden fried pockets are a popular appetizer and party snack in Lebanon.
steps: Make dough with flour, melted butter, salt, and water.
Knead until smooth, rest for 30 minutes.
Sauté onion, add ground beef and spices, cook through.
Add toasted pine nuts to meat filling.
Roll dough thin and cut circles with a cutter.
Place filling on half of each circle.
Fold over and crimp edges with a fork.
Deep fry until golden brown.
Drain on paper towels and serve hot.
cooking_tips: Dough should be smooth and pliable.
Seal edges well to prevent filling from leaking.
Can also be baked at 200°C for a lighter version.
nutrition_benefits: Protein from beef. Pine nuts provide healthy fats. A flavorful treat best enjoyed in moderation.

short_description: Open-faced meat pies topped with spiced lamb, tomatoes, and pine nuts. Often called Lebanese pizza, these thin-crusted delights are best eaten fresh from the oven.
steps: Make dough with flour, yeast, salt, oil, and water.
Let rise for 1 hour until doubled.
Mix lamb with finely diced tomatoes and onion.
Add tomato paste, spices, and pomegranate molasses.
Divide dough into small balls, roll into thin rounds.
Spread meat topping evenly, leaving thin edge.
Top with pine nuts.
Bake at 250°C (480°F) for 8-10 minutes until edges are crisp.
Serve with lemon wedges and fresh vegetables.
cooking_tips: The dough should be rolled very thin.
The topping should be raw when going into the oven.
High heat ensures crispy bottom and cooked topping.
nutrition_benefits: Protein and iron from lamb. Tomatoes provide lycopene. A balanced meal with all food groups.

short_description: Spicy Lebanese potatoes fried until crispy and tossed with garlic, cilantro, and chili. This simple side dish packs a flavorful punch.
steps: Cut potatoes into 1-inch cubes.
Fry or roast potatoes until golden and crispy.
Mince garlic and chop cilantro.
In the same pan, sauté garlic and chili flakes briefly.
Add potatoes back to the pan.
Toss with cilantro and lemon juice.
Season with salt.
Serve hot as a side dish or mezze.
cooking_tips: Don't overcrowd the pan when frying potatoes.
Add garlic at the end to prevent burning.
Adjust chili to your spice preference.
nutrition_benefits: Potatoes provide potassium and vitamin C. Garlic has immune-boosting properties. Cilantro aids digestion.

short_description: Green beans braised in olive oil with tomatoes, onions, and garlic. This healthy Lebanese classic is typically served at room temperature with bread.
steps: Trim green beans and cut into 2-inch pieces.
Sauté sliced onion in olive oil until soft.
Add minced garlic and cook briefly.
Add diced tomatoes and tomato paste.
Add green beans and enough water to barely cover.
Season with salt and allspice.
Cover and simmer until beans are very tender, about 40 minutes.
Serve at room temperature with bread.
cooking_tips: Lebanese-style beans are cooked until very soft, not crisp.
The dish is best made ahead and served the next day.
Olive oil is key - don't skimp on it.
nutrition_benefits: Green beans are rich in fiber and vitamins. Olive oil provides heart-healthy fats. Low-calorie and nutritious.

short_description: Tender zucchini stuffed with spiced rice and meat, simmered in a tangy tomato sauce. A beloved Lebanese comfort food that showcases the art of stuffed vegetables.
steps: Core zucchini using a special corer, leaving thin walls.
Mix rice with meat, spices, and a little water.
Stuff zucchini loosely - rice will expand.
Blend tomatoes with tomato paste for sauce.
Arrange stuffed zucchini in pot.
Add sliced garlic between zucchini.
Pour tomato sauce and lemon juice over.
Add water to cover halfway.
Cover and simmer for 45-60 minutes until tender.
Sprinkle with dried mint before serving.
cooking_tips: Don't overstuff - rice needs room to expand.
Use small, tender zucchini for best results.
The sauce should be slightly tangy from the lemon.
nutrition_benefits: Zucchini is low in calories and high in vitamins. Balanced combination of protein, carbs, and vegetables.

short_description: A hearty okra stew with tender lamb pieces in a rich tomato and garlic sauce. This traditional Lebanese dish is aromatic with coriander and perfectly tangy.
steps: Trim okra tops without piercing the pod.
Fry okra briefly to reduce sliminess, set aside.
Brown lamb pieces in oil, remove.
Sauté onion until soft.
Add crushed garlic and coriander, cook briefly.
Add diced tomatoes and tomato paste.
Return lamb, add water to cover, simmer until tender.
Add okra and cilantro.
Add lemon juice and simmer 20 more minutes.
Serve with rice or bread.
cooking_tips: Frying okra first helps reduce the sliminess.
Don't stir too much once okra is added.
The dish should be tangy - adjust lemon to taste.
nutrition_benefits: Okra is high in fiber and vitamin C. Lamb provides iron and B vitamins. Cilantro aids digestion.

short_description: Oil-cured baby eggplants stuffed with walnuts, garlic, and red pepper. This traditional Lebanese preserve is a prized breakfast item, aged to perfection in olive oil.
steps: Boil eggplants until just tender, about 10 minutes.
Drain and press under weight overnight to remove liquid.
Chop walnuts and mix with minced garlic and chili flakes.
Make a slit in each eggplant and stuff with walnut mixture.
Pack stuffed eggplants tightly in sterilized jars.
Cover completely with olive oil.
Let cure for at least 2 weeks before eating.
Store in refrigerator after opening.
cooking_tips: Press eggplants well - excess water causes spoilage.
Eggplants must be completely submerged in oil.
The longer they cure, the more flavorful they become.
nutrition_benefits: Walnuts provide omega-3 fatty acids. Garlic has antimicrobial properties. Eggplant is low in calories and high in fiber.

short_description: Open-faced meat pies from Baalbek, known for their distinctive boat shape and tangy meat topping with pomegranate molasses. A beloved Lebanese snack.
steps: Make soft dough with flour, yeast, oil, and water.
Let rise for 1 hour.
Mix lamb with finely diced onion and tomato.
Add tahini, pomegranate molasses, and spices.
Divide dough into small balls.
Flatten each into an oval shape.
Pinch two ends to form a boat shape.
Fill with meat mixture, top with pine nuts.
Bake at 220°C (425°F) for 12-15 minutes.
Serve with yogurt or laban.
cooking_tips: The distinctive shape comes from pinching the ends.
Tahini in the filling adds richness.
Pomegranate molasses is essential for authentic flavor.
nutrition_benefits: Protein from lamb. Complex carbs from dough. Pomegranate molasses is rich in antioxidants.

short_description: The king of kebbeh - a large dome-shaped baked kibbeh with a crispy crust and aromatic meat filling. Often served as the centerpiece of festive Lebanese meals.
steps: Soak bulgur in cold water for 30 minutes.
Process lean lamb with one grated onion and spices.
Knead lamb with drained bulgur until smooth.
For filling, sauté diced onions in butter.
Add ground lamb, cook until browned.
Add pine nuts and spices to filling.
Press half the kebbeh into an oiled dome-shaped pan.
Add filling, cover with remaining kebbeh.
Smooth the top, score decoratively.
Drizzle with olive oil.
Bake at 180°C (350°F) for 45-50 minutes until golden.
cooking_tips: Keep hands wet when shaping to prevent sticking.
The shell should be thin and even.
Serve unmolded with the dome facing up.
nutrition_benefits: High protein content. Bulgur provides fiber. Pine nuts add healthy fats and minerals.

short_description: Shortbread-like cookies filled with dates, walnuts, or pistachios, pressed into decorative wooden molds. These aromatic treats are essential for Lebanese holidays.
steps: Melt butter and mix with semolina and flour.
Let rest overnight or at least 4 hours.
Add rose water, orange blossom water, and sugar.
Knead until dough comes together.
Prepare date filling by kneading with cinnamon.
Process walnuts with sugar for walnut filling.
Take a small ball of dough, flatten, add filling.
Close and shape, press into mold if available.
Bake at 160°C (325°F) for 18-20 minutes until barely golden.
Dust with powdered sugar when cool.
cooking_tips: Don't overbake - they should remain pale.
Resting the dough is essential for proper texture.
Traditional wooden molds create beautiful patterns.
nutrition_benefits: Dates provide natural sweetness and fiber. Walnuts add omega-3 fatty acids. Rose water has calming properties.
